awd_titl_txt: From Cool to Ultracool: Investigating Magnetism and Rotation in the Smallest Stars and Ultra Cool Dwarfs
awd_abstract_narration:
Alejandro Nunez is awarded a Mathematical and Physical Sciences Ascending Postdoctoral Research Fellowship (MPS-Ascend) to conduct a program of research and education at Columbia University. Dr. Nunez plans a rotational and magnetic activity census for 13 open star clusters, using public archives of ground and space-based observatories, complemented with dedicated observations collected during the Fellowship. Based on these observations, he plans a study of the dependence of activity on rotation, paying particular attention to ultra-cool dwarfs, at the different ages of the open clusters to be studied.  Dr. Nunez will mentor participants in the Columbia University Bridge to the Ph.D. program. 

Dr. Nunez will compare different activity indicators to test competing theories describing magnetic heating of stellar atmospheres. Despite several decades of theoretical and observational efforts, an accurate, quantitative description of the age-rotation-activity relation remains elusive. He seeks to answer several fundamental theoretical questions. He intends to quantify the dependence of rotation and magnetic activity on quantities such as the degree of core-envelope coupling and the magnetic field geometry. For the Bridge to Ph. D. program, his responsibilities will include tracking the progress of participants, gathering feedback, and by organizing activities that foster a sense of community among the participants and that help them in their professional development. He will provide consistent, high-quality, field-specific advising and mentoring to participants.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
I published a journal paper on the magnetic activity-rotation relation the open clusters Praesepe and Hyades, in which I present my analysis of X-ray and rotational data for stars in these two clusters. I found that at ≈700 Myr, only M dwarfs (stars with no more than 60% Solar mass) remain saturated in X-rays, with only tentative evidence for supersaturation. I found a tight relation between the Rossby number (rotational period divided by convective turnover time) and the ratio between X-ray and bolometric luminosity in unsaturated single members, suggesting a power-law index between −3.2 and −3.9. I also found that at ≈700 Myr, K and M dwarfs (stars with no more than 80% Solar mass) display very low metal abundances in their stellar coronae, with a typical value of 0.2 Solar, whereas F and G dwarfs (greater than 80% Solar mass) have a typical abundance of 0.4 Solar. Lastly, I found no difference in the coronal metal abundance and temperature between binary and single members in Praesepe and Hyades.

I published a paper analyzing the relationship between rotation and chromospheric and coronal activity, using H-alpha emission and X-ray emission measurements, respectively, for stars in the ≈700 Myr-old clusters Hyades and Praesepe. I report that stars rotating at super fast speeds show a decrease in their X-ray emission compared to similar stars that are rotating more slowly, but the same stars do not show a decrease in their H-alpha emission. This serves as compeling evidence that the decrease in X-rays is driven by centrifugal stripping of the corona, where the outermost layers of the stellar atmosphere are being lost due to centrifugal forces. This paper will finally show clear evidence for coronal stripping in M dwarfs, the smallest and coolest type of stars.

I also found a tight relation between the Rossby number (rotational period divided by convective turnover time) and the ratio between H-alpha (a chromospheric indicator) and bolometric luminosity in unsaturated single members, suggesting a power-law index of −5.9. This is significantly steeper than that of the coronal indicator (X-rays) for the same stars. This suggests that chromospheric activity decays much more quickly than coronal activity as stars spin down.

In an upcoming paper on the rotation-activity relation in the ≈600 Myr-old open cluster Coma Berenices, I report that stellar metallicity appears to affect the spindown of low-mass stars. When we compare the rotation and activity distribution of Coma Ber stars, which have solar-type metallicity, against those in Praesepe, which have super solar metallicity, we find a non-negligible offset, which may indicate a slower spindown for the lower metallicity stars. This is an expected theoretical result that will serve as observational confirmation.

I published PHEW (originally created by M. Alam in 2016), a set of Python tools to measure the equivalent width, line depth, and full width at half maximum of any spectral line.

For Broader Impacts, 12 Bridge Program to PhD scholars were mentored during the duration of this award. I provided them with tools and feedback to improve their presentations and school applilcations and provided support to help maintain life-work balance. The majority of the scholars who applied for graduate school programs in their fields were accepted and successfully moved to graduate school after finishing the Program.
